body.p:
As your monthly has been
presented I presume that my ladyship may claim
a portion of your time without having it distracted
by more important matter: for let me tell you
my dear Sir I like not to be numbered with the
public in your esteem or attention; & you are sadly
mistaken, if you think that by hearing from you
through your Occident I am repaid for a reply
to my favors. But badinage aside I like to
read you as you are not clad in your holy day
garb to meet the public scrutiny, but plain friend
Leeser with all his odd notions & novel views of men & things
The world has tended somewhat to improve me, as they
shew me, that I am a very insignificant personage to
them, without the claims which fortune Talent or
beauty give But to my friends I am still something
of une enfante gaté & not content with demi
favors. Therefore have I punished myself by not
writing before, that when I did I should receive your
undivided attention I am not willing to recognize
you in your works, for you appear so august that
I should never dare to enjoy the pleasure of writing
my thoughts as they flow to you. Believe me you
are two in one & two very distinct personages.

body.p:
I often think of
them with much
pleasure—Will
you be kind
enough to remem
ber me also to

if she has yet

Yrs resptly
Sarah Anna

Edward and

Our weather has been & continues intensely cold with
rain & damp in place of sunshine & a dry genial
atmosphere. We can hardly be comfortable with large
fires & extra cloathing for our houses are not built
for extreme cold nor are our servants prepared for
it; there is something in their nature repugnant
to cold & like the beaver they would remain torpid
until Spring if our demands on their services were
not so imperative. We have had some of your
citizens among us who seem astonished to meet the
cold winds of winter instead of spring & flowers:
Among our strangers are Mrs B Henry & daughter
of your city very fashionable people. The Mother
a very intelligent fascinating woman who has
been beautiful but the scythe of father Time has
nearly destroyed it all! The daughter is a beautiful
blonde brought up too much in fashionable
to inherit her mothers talents or acquirements. As
they were with their relatives the Henrys I saw much
of them. We have also a Mrs & Mr Aulden residents
of Philadelphia Mr A is chaplin in the Navy & alth
-ough very cultivated & accomplished people, moving
in a different circle from the Henrys in your city
but receiving much attention in ours. I am happy
to learn the good fortune of our friends & trust as they
increase in worldly goods so may they in piety
& religion & may their purses & hearts be ever open
to the wants of their fellow creatures. While the Fickle
God is so liberally pouring his blessings on some of

your friends could you not allure him to bestow a few
of his favors on a certain friend of yours who would
endeavour to make good use of them. I am glad you
have by your perseverance succeeded in organizing a
Jewish publication Society in America May you be
able to carry out your plan. I feel assured many bless-
ings will attend your exertions & the poor will more
particularly feel the advantage of your untiring
efforts. I said from what I could learn you would
have many subscribers in Charleston & you have
taken a sensible course by acting under the rose
& making it appear as if you were only an agent
& not an originator of this good object! Those who
know you feel that the benifit of the Jews & their
Salvation is your highest aim. Like all great men
your good deeds will live after you & this must
console you for the many hard rubs you have
received from those you have by your independence
prejudiced you against you. I have inclosed the poetry
I would satisfy your curiosity which seems to be equal to
a womans but The Dying Hebrew was sent S A by a
friend & we know not the author. Mana? is not re-
converted that I know of, she is not however more
advanced in the Christian faith as she only attends church
occasionally-but she rides & goes to parties on Sabbath
in truth I cannot tell what she is for she appears
different at different times. I do not believe she is writing
or studying any thing & I asked Anna & she said she
knew no more than I did about it. Her Father reques

ted her to examine the scriptures before she decided & she
may be making up her mind. She is my relative but I think
her of the ? Worldly entré nous. As S A wishes
to add a few lines, I must conclude after requesting
you to remember me to all those who ask after
me. What can a plain moderate sized bible with
good print be bought at? We want them for our
Sunday school. May your health & strength be equal to your
exertions in the cause of our blessed faith prays an unworthy
member of the house of Israel

Mother asked me to copy
the piece sent, I hope it will suit you, and
if it does, I have another given me by the
same friend thought I am acquainted with the
authoress. The other piece is called “Rachael's
pillar in the wilderness” and though the style
is quite simple I think it pretty. Perhaps it
is requisite for you, to have only superior pro
ductions, if so I fear my contributions will
be deemed unworthy. There are a few questions
Dear Sir that I have for some time wished
to have answered satisfactorily, if it would
not be too much trouble I would really
feel indebted if you would explain them.
Pray excuse this informal visit of mine, you
no doubt deem me an intruder, but forgive this first
act & like the children I promise not to do so again
Pray give my love to cousin A & R. Hart and tell them
